article.description:
Kirk Hinrich scored 23 points and Nick
Collison had 15 points and 12 rebounds as No. 7 Kansas routed Texas
A&M 85-45 Wednesday night despite losing Wayne Simien to another
painful injury.

related.description:
Kansas forward Wayne Simien, who missed
six weeks earlier this season with a dislocated right shoulder,
left Wednesday night's game against Texas A&M after the shoulder popped out again.
related.linkText: Kansas' Simien leaves game after shoulder pops out
related.title: Simien recovering from dislocated shoulder
related.headline: Simien recovering from dislocated shoulder

article.headline: Hinrich, Collison help Kansas jump on Aggies early

images.name: Simien_Wayne 030226 Vert top
images.caption: Wayne Simien is expected to play Saturday against Oklahoma State.

article.linkText: Simien injures shoulder in Kansas' rout of Texas A&M
article.story: LAWRENCE, Kan. (AP) -- Even without Wayne Simien, No. 7 Kansas had no trouble against Texas A&M. Kirk Hinrich scored 23 points and Nick Collison had 15 points and 12 rebounds as the Jayhawks took over sole possession of first place in the Big 12 with an 85-45 victory Wednesday night. "We came out hard and defended and never gave up,'' Collison said. "We've gotten up pretty big on some teams in the past but let them back in.'' Early in the game, Simien grimaced in apparent agony as his right shoulder, which was dislocated earlier in the season, popped out again. Trainer Mark Cairns said the shoulder popped back into place before Simien was helped to the locker room, meaning that technically it was not a second dislocation. But it was not clear when the 6-foot-9 sophomore would be able to return. Simien averages nearly 16 points and nine rebounds and is a key to Kansas' chances of repeating as Big 12 champions and going back to the Final Four. "He was in pretty good pain,'' Cairns said. Aaron Miles added 10 points and 10 assists as the Jayhawks (21-6, 11-2) held the Aggies (13-11, 5-8) to the lowest point total by a conference opponent in Roy Williams' 15 years as Kansas coach. With Oklahoma's loss at Missouri, Kansas took a one-game lead over the Sooners in the Big 12. Collison said Simien "didn't seem like he was in too much pain once they got him calmed down.'' "It's tough for Wayne, and it's tough on our team not having him.'' Even without Simien, Kansas had the Aggies outclassed from beginning to end. Texas A&M scored the first basket, then Kansas went on an 18-2 run. Collison finished with his ninth double-double of the season and Keith Langford had 18 points. Missing from long, short and medium range, the Aggies shot only 7-of-35 in the first half and trailed 48-18 at halftime. Then they missed 12 of their first 14 shots in the second half as the Jayhawks seized a 59-23 lead. Bernard King, the Big 12's career scoring leader, was hounded most of the night by Hinrich and scored only seven points, a season low, on 2-of-9 shooting. "They did a good job on everyone, not just Bernard,'' Texas A&M coach Melvin Watkins said. "I saw us standing around a little bit and we didn't get any second chances.'' Texas A&M players were not allowed to speak to reporters. "We just didn't have it tonight,'' Watkins said. "Kansas is one of the best teams at taking advantage of our missed opportunities. They forced us to take some tough shots.'' For the game, Texas A&M shot only 26 percent and was outrebounded 52-37. Williams said he knows he's going to get criticized for playing Simien, who also tweaked the shoulder last week against Colorado and said it "felt like somebody was jamming a fork into my shoulder.'' "I worry about him when we're jumping around in the locker room before we go out for the game,'' Williams said. "It's my choice and his choice to play with pain or don't play. He chose to play. "Everybody thinks they're coaches and say, `Well, you shouldn't play him against A&M.' "You only have so many opportunities to play.'' It was his Simien's fourth game back since hurting the shoulder Jan. 4. Kansas, which is 8-0 all-time against Texas A&M, had 35 rebounds in the first half, three short of the school record. Kansas' closest margin of victory in going 4-0 at home in Big 12 play against the Aggies has been 29 points. Tomas Ress and Leandro Garcia-Morales each had nine points for the Aggies.
